title: Will a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) declaration pertaining to the Wuhan coronavirus (COVID-19) be in effect as of 6 May 2020?
preds:
Still in effect.
As of about four days ago, WHO scientists met and confirmed the PHEIC would remain in effect.
On 1 May the WHO's International Health Regulations Emergency Committee unanimously agreed that the outbreak still constitutes a PHEIC, and the WHO is unlikely to act contrary to its recommendation.
Guess the virus is not going anywhere anytime soon.  And why would the WHO withdraw it? Given the criticism.
Still major numbers of cases in many countries
i feel their time has passed, no?  if it expires every three months...
there is no sign of all countries moving past the peak.
Current declarations of President supports this declaration.
Only 2 weeks left. Current WHO risk assessment: global level - very high. Will stay so for at least 2 more months.
It was done back in January?

With the continued progress, highly unlikely this will be withdrawn by that time. The declaration was well in place before the current explosion of cases. We'll be dealing with this globally until well past May.
The outbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 30 January 2020.  Many areas of the world will not peak until late April/early May.

It apparently was declared before this question opened. 
Since 2009 there have been six PHEIC declarations:[6] the 2009 H1N1 (or swine flu) pandemic, the 2014 polio declaration, the 2014 outbreak of Ebola in Western Africa, the 2015–16 Zika virus epidemic,[7] the ongoing 2018–20 Kivu Ebola epidemic,[8] and the ongoing 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, declared a PHEIC by the Director-General on 30 January 2020.[9] The recommendations are temporary and require reviews every three months.[2]
The number of infected people is not even close to the high on the majority of countries in the world. And the lack of leadership is getting the things worst.
Highly unlikely this will change in the period provided.
Italy just leveling off now, 6 weeks for US to follow, 3-4 weeks more than reasonable for other countries behind the curve.

Going all in, looking at the history of PHEICs.  The shortest PHEIC from declaration to termination appears to be over 1 year, and some e.g. poliovirus is still considered a PHEIC, 5.5 years later (https://news.un.org/en/story/2020/01/1054921).
viruses don't respect boarders mexico india south africa middle east will be devastated

Covid-19 is a very popular and extravagantly concerned disease. Therefore, it will most probably be announced as PHEIC.
https://www.theguardian.com/global/2020/jan/30/coronavirus-what-other-public-health-emergencies-has-the-who-declared

The more social distancing the longer the pandemic will take to resolve, so things are likely to still be serious in May. As Wuhan start to life quarantine I think we will see another wave of infections early April, going into another cycle of quarantine.  I think it will take 4 of these cycles to start coming back to normal with heard immunity which is unlikely to be until June
Don't see it dipping below PHEIC status by then.
It's a global pandemic. It will take at least 12 weeks to contain it in most countries.
China is well past the peak of Covid19 due to stringent lockdown and will start relaxing lockdown rules in Wuhan gradually and.by May all restrictions would have been lifted
It is going to take time even if a cure is found to distribute the cure

There are too many countries still low on the exponential outbreak curve that when May rolls around they'll be in the thick of viral outbreaks across many countries currently not talked much about in the media.
It will remain in effect until a vaccine is found

There are a lot of populous countries who are still learning how to cope with the transmission of the virus. There are many more who haven’t yet experienced widespread transmission. I think the major concern will still have a few months to run yet.
Despite improvements in the situation in Wuhan, it is highly unlikely that the declaration will be cancelled given the lack of clarity regarding infection rates elsewhere.
3 months in and this is only escalating. If the pattern of growth follows the same as China in every country we should be at the peak between May and August.
In the US, all variables about Covid-19 are getting worse. Only China and S. Korea have case reductions.  Also, I can't envision a PHEIC being lifted while thousands per month are dying.
According to the british government it will peak around that date. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/15/uk-coronavirus-crisis-to-last-until-spring-2021-and-could-see-79m-hospitalised

1. Negative effect on OECD countries and recent declaration of pandemic.
2. Incubation period is up to 2 weeks, doubling of number every week and the length of the curve is approximately 6 weeks. Major Western countries are just at the  beginning.
I doubt the epidemiological situation will be resolved by May, it is too soon for a vaccine to have been developed
Every country in Europe has a case.
It's going to get worse before it gets better.
Without a vaccine, the effectiveness of other measures (quarantine, isolation, warmer weather ....) will likely not contain the spread.

Doctors have been eager to conclude that 40-70% of the global population has the potential to get this virus, and with potentially increased testing then by May potentially +1 million persons may have confirmed to be positive. This will increase panic and the potential for the 40-70% target to be reached if not properly contained. However if the fatality (revised due to availability of more data) rate is sub 0.2% or there is a steep decline (taper in the spread plus recoveries) in rates due to the end of the flu season, then there would be no need for a public heath Emergency post May. During the summer this will be withdrawn.

The spreading of the coronavirus perhaps will slow down soon in developed worlds. For the biggest outbreaks, in China, Hubei province accounts for the vast majority of cases and death, that is mainly due to wrong policy. None of the other provinces comes nearly as bad. The other pace having very bad outbreak is Iran, which is also largely due to government stumbles. Most other parts of the the world has better transparency, the the results will not be too bad. Most likely the spread will slow down in March and April.

The SARS and seasonal flu diagnosed cases would suggest this would suggest that peak infections would probably dissipate by the back end of May (northern Hemisphere). Even then the WHO needs to consider how this will hit the southern hemisphere during there winter months (peak cold and flu time). so will almost certainly not reduce the risk until they have that info  
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002%E2%80%9304_SARS_outbreak#/media/File:2003_Probable_cases_of_SARS_-_Worldwide.svg

CV-19 has a slow incubate period but a fast viral shedding while maintaining a low r-naught rate. The panic will wane and grow again. Supply chains have run out of masks, hand sterilizers, some industrial sterilants-- many of which are manufactured in China who is holding the largest demand on backorder of these products at this time. The spread isn't going to stop.

The epidemic is only just starting to take off in many countries (UK went from 51 to 85 cases in a day). Other posters have made the point that infections are probably under-reported too. The only way the PHEIC might be cancelled would be if the disease had demonstrably peaked in most countries. Perhaps it may peak in the countries that were initially hardest hit (China and neighbours) but most other countries, not least the US, have a lot of room for growth in cases before they peak.

I don't believe the international numbers will have stabilized by then. If it started in China in December and wasn't announced for a month, and only now, three months in, are numbers are starting to stabilize in Wuhan. This appears to indicate places like Milan and Iran have not yet peaked, and will not stabilize for three months after the first reports, so eight to ten weeks. Over that point, other nations will yet to peak. I expect the PHEIC will remain in effect well into the summer.

In the face of pressure on economies globally, there may be attempts to influence the decision of this outcome. This risk will be increased by any short term success in containment measures that reduce the growth rate in recorded cases which may lead to a false sense of security.
Update: US clearly struck by community transmission
Because of the RO rate and the fact that cases are popping up in locations not previously discussed and the number of deaths in Iran belie the actual  number infected.
Update: Vaccine-development efforts might be slightly undermined.

This is tricky one, because they were initially nomen omen resistant - but they argued only in terms of geography, and now there is no way it will be confined to single place like in China. The second step will be to acquire mechanical knowledge about the disease. They lifted Zika PHEIC when the link to microcephaly was considered "robust". They also meddled with Ebola PHEIC/not-PHEIC in political terms (10.1016/S0140-6736(19)31406-0), so there are more factors to this. At the same time, the timeline seems pretty easy, that is they don't have in habit to LIFT PHEIC so quickly and that declaration was definitely in the context of 30th January (10x less cases than today!), so May seems safe.

The covid-19 outbreak situation is serious.  New infected cases have been found in many countries outside China.  Some of these countries do not have the expertise, infrastructure and resources to handle potential outbreaks.  I believe that outbreaks outside China will get worse soon, and it won't recover before 6 May.
the WHO is compromised but if it wants to retain any credibility and future funding then it has to declare it

Just recently the CDC released a statement that they expect COVID-19 to spread in the US and become a pandemic even using the phrase "It's more a question of when." The CDC has been preparing to stop the spread but the White House maintains that the disease is under control. This lack of proper communication to the public is indicative of a larger lack of communication or even plain ignorance between public health official and the executive branch which could make the problem in the US much worse than need be. The WHO has also recently (Feb 24, 2020) stated that despite a reported decrease in infections in China, the spread may not be contained globally as cases in Italy, Iran, and South Korea grow. The WHO's fear of a pandemic is enough for me to think that this outbreak will continue for several more months at the level of a PHEIC.

According to the New York Times, CDC officials warned that Americans should prepare for COVID-19 to spread in the US. The secretary of health and human services told a Senate panel that federal and local health departments would need as many as 300 million additional masks for healthcare providers. Moreover, there has been a spike in cases in Iran, Korea and Italy. Investors are also preparing for global economic malaise, as evidenced by large drops in the S&P 500, FTSE, Nikkei, Dax, and crude oil prices.

The purpose of a PHEIC is to help ensure states share information about the relevant disease to better inform global strategy. Given the current rapid spreading of the virus, I think this will likely still be necessary in the WHO director general's eyes.
I think that while a vaccine will be containing the virus, new cases will still be diagnosed worldwide.
It looked like it is slowing in China but spreading elsewhere. Raising for now. One of these days I should do the math to model the chances.
The WHO does not have a ranking above PHEIC and there is no foreseeable outcome other than escalation of community spread in more countries.
No better news. Looks like it's getting worse.

While China got (more or less) control of the situation, new developments are of concern - Italy, Iran, S. Korea... Fortunately, not in Africa (except Egypt) and Latin America  yet. looks contained in India. Unless these mentioned outbreaks are contained and no other countries get involved, the declaration stays in place.
worldwide spread, COVID is not going anywhere. May significantly disrupt travel worldwide.
Rock solid data required before they un-declare it. If the pandemic were to rekindle after emergency is scaled down, WHO would lose face.

The spread to area’s in combination with no link found to travelers from China means a unpredictable spread is possible. After a week 1 on 7 needs medical treatment. Of those 1/8 wil die. 
The unexpected spread and the dead making no destinction between sick or healthy people make the perfect couple for a pandemic. 
If anymore country’s are confronteert with unexpected sick a pheic is highly possible.
Spreading but also slowing down. Mixed.
Very unlikely to revoked since quickly when (1) bureaucrats/technocrats (2) likely still regular deaths  as in same bucket as SARS

While confirmed COVID-19 cases in China are dropping off, there is a sharp rise in confirmed cases outside of China - several new countries have reported sustained person-to-person cases in the past three days (Iran, Lebanon, and Israel) and new cases are rising exponentially in South Korea, Italy, Japan and Iran [1, 2]. As such, there is the very real possibility that we are on the "brink of a pandemic" [3]. Moreover, a new analysis out today by a infectious disease modelling team at Imperial College London has estimated that "two thirds of COVID-19 cases exported from mainland China have remained undetected worldwide" - so the situation outside of China is probably worse than is being reported. I am thus revising my estimate upward as to the likelihood of a PHEIC declaration remaining in effect on May 6. [1] https://www.statnews.com/2020/02/21/coronavirus-picking-up-steam-outside-china/
[2] https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/02/22/808440540/coronavirus-cases-triple-in-south-korea-who-keeps-eye-on-africa-iran
[3] https://www.cnn.com/videos/health/2020/02/22/anthony-fauci-on-coronavirus-smerconish-vpx.cnn
[4] https://www.imperial.ac.uk/news/195564/two-thirds-covid-19-cases-exported-from-mainland/
While cases in China appear to be slowing down, more cases have been appearing and spreading  in other parts of the world. The emergency alert will be here for a long time.

Update my argument and increased forecast from 95 to 98%. 1)The WHO should be notified if any two of the four following questions are affirmed:
Is the public health impact of the event serious?
Is the event unusual or unexpected?
Is there a significant risk for international spread?
Is there a significant risk for international travel or trade restrictions? Three of these questions might be answered and affirmed: the event is unusual in terms of the long incubation period of the virus in humans. If there is confirmation that patients without syntoms and without being ill spread the virus, then possibly this issue will be considered as unexpected or unusual. There is significant risk of international spread as result of long incubation period where carriers are not aware of their spread level. In 52 days, 26 countries have been infected already, so the rate of infection is faster than previous pandemics like Swine flu in 2009. Nevertheless, it doesn’t show a high rate of mortality. There is significant risk of international travel and trade restrictions as the virus spreads rapidly, then countries are imposing travel restrictions. Because China has imposed internal bans, then factories are not producing, and has impact on international trade. Nevertheless, this issue does not constitute a trade restriction directly but might have an impact on trade in terms of decrease of products offer, hence, there might be a price increase for customers. 
2)Autumn in the South hemisphere is about to start, and this might lead to addition of newly infected countries. Some of these countries are not prepared with resources to fight against a massive spread of the virus, for example, some countries in Asia (Iran), South America and Africa with inadequate or unprepared health services.
3)As the increase of infected people is faster than in other pandemics, then production of medicines might not be able to cope with a high demand. For this reason, developed countries might also not be able to provide support to poor countries as they will give priority to their own citizens. Also, politicians might use the pandemic as a leverage tool for achieving gains in negotiations with China.
4)Despite the competition amogst differnt research centres, the development of a vaccine against the virus is expected for 2021, longer than in other pandemics. In march 2020, first trials (phase one) will start in mice. Then, if successful, a second phase for testing main effects in humans will follow. And third phase for testing different dosis in order to find the appropriate formulae for increasing effectiveness in humans will continue before commercialisation. Usually, each phase takes between 3 to 6 months until results and data analysis are obtained.
5)China is also trying to avoid the media storm while in trade negotiations with the US, and therefore, might also be providing innacurate data, which eventually will come to the light. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_Emergency_of_International_Concern
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_flu_pandemic
https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/24/health/24flu.html
https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019
https://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-7995583/How-killer-coronavirus-compares-SARS-swine-flu-Ebola-Interactive-map.html
https://larepublica.pe/economia/2020/02/14/coronavirus-afecta-primera-fase-del-acuerdo-comercial-entre-china-y-estados-unidos/
https://larepublica.pe/mundo/2020/02/13/coronavirus-aliexpress-cancelo-pedidos-a-espana-por-el-covid-19-enfermedad-oms-fotos/
https://larepublica.pe/sociedad/2020/02/11/coronavirus-peru-se-descarta-presencia-de-virus-y-se-activan-protocolos/
https://www.lavanguardia.com/vida/20200215/473557546877/coronavirus-wuhan-casos-fallecidos-sintomas-china-espana-mwc-2020-barcelona-gsma-ultimas-noticias-hoy-en-directo.html
Today, WHO  worried about COVID-19 expanding outside China.

Increased number of cases in Japan, South Korea, and Iran will likely lead to extension of heightened awareness of the Coronavirus and therefor the PHEIC. WHO will likely keep PHEIC in effect in order to keep awareness for COVID-19 high and prevent it from becoming a seasonal flu.
China will make a great effort to contain the spread, and if successful it will lobby for removing the  PHEIC.

Recent scientific research suggests Coronaviruses are able to jump from bats directly to people. Replied yes because vaccine for this one may be developed soon but another slightly different coronavirus is quite likely.

Once a PHEIC is declared it will stay in effect until the virus is under control. The number of cases or infected will need to dropping dramatically. There's no sign of this and it's unlikely it'll happen before the next meeting. As another forecaster mentioned, the shortest PHEIC duration was 8.5 months.

WHO defines a PHEIC as "an extraordinary event which is determined to constitute a public health risk to other States through the international spread of disease and to potentially require a coordinated international response". Previously they were invoked for swine flu, polio, Ebola and Zika virus. The criteria are open to interpretation, with previous declarations and non-declarations having been challenged. Outside view
Of the five PHEIC declared previously, the shortest duration was 8.5 months (for Zika virus). Two (polio and Ebola) are still in effect. It seems that WHO may be conservative about declaring a PHEIC, partly for political considerations, but once it is declared it is likely to stay in effect until WHO has a high level of assurance that the disease is under control. Inside view
In this case, there is a high degree of uncertainty about the likely spread of the disease, partly due to the long incubation period which means more people being unknowingly infected and therefore continuing to infect others (https://hubbardresearch.com/estimating-infections-2019-coronavirus-underreporting/). There are already sizable numbers of reported infections elsewhere in Asia (https://www.medpagetoday.com/infectiousdisease/publichealth/84698) which imply larger numbers of people unknowingly infected. Even if there is no major spread to Western countries, these will almost definitely take longer than three months to stabilise. And even a small number of new cases in a country with no reported cases today will raise the level of concern.
No signs of slowing down; deaths in S Korea
due to the level of international travelm
Based on the history of previous declarations, it is unlikely to be lifted by 6 May even if the disease appears well controlled at that date
The virus will be less virulent and more widespread
Looks like it is spreading rapidly.  Unknown numbers and locations of asymptomatic  carriers from cruise ships.

Raising percentage from 95-97% because of infected ship releases, Japanese situation & Iranian fatalities.  Both Iranian victims were elderly locals who hadn't traveled abroad, meaning they were infected by contagious unknowns.  Since death rate is approx 2% that means there are likely at least 100 infected & potentially uncontained individuals in region making a more serious outbreak akin to that of China, but without China's infection management capacity, inevitable.  Given regional instability it seems likely such an outbreak will (or already has) spread further still into nations with yet poorer health facilities & conditions for containment.  Whether or not the virus is still deemed an emergency by May 6th may depend on its ability to survive changing temperatures & jump the equator.  Relative winter temperatures and humidity levels in Australia, S America & NZ etc suggest it would be relatively easy for the virus to survive & thrive given access to these nations via undiagnosed (or late diagnosed) travelers over the coming months.  All of this presupposes the unknown of mutation.  If it burns itself out I may be completely wrong.  If it adapts to different hosts, conditions, crosses to other species or becomes more contagious, we may see much worse, globally, than China has already experienced & over a significant period of time.  Nb:  It's unlikely many nations will have the capacity or will to imposes draconian containment protocols on its citizens as China & the virus is believed to have a 9 day life span on surfaces outside the body - two reasons to think China may still be the tip of the ultimate infection pool iceberg.
COVID-19 is as yet an unknown. While fatality rates still seem low, it is unclear how long the virus can live outside the host, how it is spread or when/if a vaccine will be available.

Based on the Public Health Emergency of International Concern criteria:
- constitutes a public health risk to other States through the international spread of disease; and
- potentially requires a coordinated international response  And given the spread of COVID-19 around the world with Japan, Egypt, India  and Iran confirming new cases it is highly likely that PHEIC be in effect as of 6 May. At the same time it is a realistic possibility that China's daily infection figures will continue to drop but with an increase in the number of deaths.

Borders of affected nations remain highly porous to asymptomatic carriers.  Inadequate testing protocols & availability in countries with large international connectivity hubs.  Transmission of virus to nations with poor containment facilities seems inevitable.  Infection rate may die off in currently affected countries as warmer weather arrives, only to take a hold in those countries heading into Autumn. Over the last few years Australia has seen earlier and larger cold & flu spikes, making the potential transmission of coronavirus under ambient conditions more likely.  There's some chance 6 May may fall between the subsidence of northern hemisphere cases & rise in southern hemisphere transmission, but the virus is contagious enough to suppose that it'll have already started affecting nations with a very poor ability to contain it by then, perpetuating global concern.
3 charts that compare coronavirus to previous outbreaks https://flip.it/FeQqmJ Japan losing control of infected number

Although cases are likely to drop,cases outside of China will increase (although not contribute to the overall forecast of cases globally), as a consequence increased transmission rates in certain countries, particularly those with lower standards of health care provision, wil! Result in the WHO maintaining its current PHEIC until rate of virus transmission significantly decreases.  Further forecasts should be reviewed when death rates in countries with lower standards of health care provision emerge.
The COVID-19 number of infections/deaths will drop significantly
China working to contain cases, new people in to manage cases in Wuhan. Reluctance to raise public concern.
Based on the early containment and global awareness I believe the virus will be largely contained to China, and will have a fall in reported cases from March-July.
Will be in place before then but by may anti vaccine in place
Circulation within populations outside of China will be the likely cause.
We don't have a vaccine yet. And all indications seem to suggest that the virus has gone international.
The number of infected and geographic spread is continuing to expand.  I believe that official Chinese reporting is undercounted, both due to intentional and unintentional effects.

If plague inc. has thought me anything it's that the virus needs to mutate to be successful but if caught early and the right level of coordination is achieved the virus will burn out. the downside is the collaborative nature of the Chinese - they may not want to
Cases in china decreasing and virus contained in other countries at the moment
The reports of the virus have significantly gone down recently worldwide. I predict that this epidemic will not become a wide-scale pandemic.
due to Chinas wrong data conclutions might be wrong as well
I expect transmissions to have slowed from the peak by then, but not ceased entirely, and so this will still be classed as a PHEIC.

50% yes or no.
Current rate of spread increase by 10%
Quarantine procedures decrease by 10%
New meds possible e.g. Use of liquorice (poss reduction in sars through liquorice tea) decrease by 10%
Increase in number of deaths possible increase by 10%
14 day quarantine not adhered to outside of China inrease by 10%
Spread to countries less able to cope medically increase by 10%

I have worked in infectious diseases and I am confident that given the nature of transmission and incubation period, this will spread to a point it becomes a global concern and public health emergency.

very high transmissibility (much higher than SARS, which was contained within 8 months), and the world is much more interconnected than it was back at the time of the last pandemic of this type, including developing countries with unsophisticated healthcare systems.

Stabilisation of cases plus increased measures in China make the likelihood of a pandemic close to nill - that, alongside an increasing lower death-rate both within China  & externally makes it less concerning than the common cold.
five in ten years and Covid-19 spreads much faster than they did
Likely to increase if the virus spreads from China - effectiveness of quarantine measures are unknown.

Public health experts recently "assembled before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee with some worrisome warnings: The dangerous Wuhan novel coronavirus is probably already in the United States in greater numbers than we know and should show itself in clusters in the coming weeks. There’s reason to doubt its spread will die down when the weather warms. And it could ultimately affect hundreds of thousands of Americans."
https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/02/12/health-experts-sound-alarm-trump-fights-coronavirus-with-alternative-facts/

The virus shows clear signs of accelerated spreading, and on current trends it is inconceivable that the situation will be less serious on 6 May than it was on 30 January. On the contrary, the situation will be several orders of magnitude worse.

If current preventive measures hold, no, no need for PHEIC - the outbreak seems to be abating, especially in other countries. And China is a VERY big player to push for the change. Of course, the measures may not hold, especially in some developing countries.

Viruses evolve over time by natural selection. The virus wants to survive and propagate so will evolve not to kill its host. Severity will decrease over time. I dont know if this will happen by may 6th but certainly by June.
Chinese will do all they can to stop this type of declaration
PHEICs typically last a long time and the WHO will be reluctant to lift it prematurely. That it's not 100% is because of the the limited scope of the spread outside China so far.

It seems probable that the virus will escape confinement, though there is a reasonable chance it will not. However, there also seems to be considerable uncertainty about the fatality rate, particularly as it is not clear that (particularly within China) all infections are being recorded
PHEIC's for Ebola and Zika have remained active for long timeframes. Given the spread of COVID-19 so far in China and Pacific Rim I think it's unlikely it will burn out in the next 3 months
It appears like the first phase of COVID-19 crisis. By May, 2020 there will be more clarity about the severity of the crisis.
my first new forecast for some time
This will not be going away until a vaccine is being widely distributed. That is unlikely to happen this year.
The infection rate appears to be lowering. Yet this also happened a week ago.  People in quarantine are returning home but is the period long enough to clear possible spread

In 2 weeks it Will be visable  if the stricter and stricter containment of people within their quarters wil show effect and is sustainable. for the party it has to be. The number of death and sick people wil be higher then public will be told. the phiec wil know this and zee it as a matter of international concern because of the spread within China.
There is a loper probability that cases outside Wuhan will not rise.

The WHO has not lifted a PHEIC in less than 6 months since the declaration was first used. Moreover, given the SARS outbreak lasted approximately six months, it is reasonable to expect this coronavirus outbreak to continue through May.

Draconian measures allowed by an autocratic government to Isolate the population in Wuhan in particular and China in general; precautions taken by the travel industry (that has tremendous financial incentives to stop the outbreak); monitoring at ports-of-entry; precautions in health clinics and hospitals; greater public awareness - all will mitigate the incidence of COVID-19 below the emergency threshold by May 6.
No one declared public emergency so far, now the number of infections are not so high.
It seems likely that coronavirus will still present a significant global threat at this time, but there will also be political pressure to declare the outbreak under control.
The numbers of deaths have stabilised and should soon start decreasing. There's still a potential for surprise from the Chinese authority, like what happened with the change in diagnostic methods.

very low death rates... because already there is a lot of panic and governments and people are taking extra ordinary precautions.. including travel and other restrictions... it is probably going to be under total control within 2-3 months..
I am easily convinced by the arguements put forth by @ADA2045 and @jayb that the PHEIC will still be in place.
They have not yet removed some warnings for other diseases such as Zika. This won't be much different.
@ADA2045 and @jayb make some good arguments here.  I'm going to jump in at 90%.
I believe this is just emerging

1)The WHO should be notified if any two of the four following questions are affirmed:
    Is the public health impact of the event serious?
    Is the event unusual or unexpected?
    Is there a significant risk for international spread?
    Is there a significant risk for international travel or trade restrictions?  
Three of these questions might be answered and affirmed: the event is unusual in terms of the long incubation period of the virus in humans. There is significant risk of international spread as result of long incubation period where carriers are not aware of their spread level. In 52 days, 26 countries have been infected already, so the rate of infection is faster than previous pandemics like Swine flu in 2009. Nevertheless, it doesn’t show a high rate of mortality. There is significant risk of international travel and trade restrictions as the virus spreads rapidly, then countries are imposing travel restrictions. Because China has imposed internal bans, then factories are not producing, and has impact on international trade. Nevertheless, this issue does not constitute a trade restriction directly but might have an impact on trade in terms of decrease of products offer, hence, there might be a price increase for customers.
2)Autumn in the South hemisphere is about to start, and this might lead to addition of newly infected countries. Some of these countries are not prepared with resources to fight against a massive spread of the virus, for example, some countries in South America and Africa with inadequate or unprepared health services.
3)As the increase of infected people is faster than in other pandemics, then production of medicines might not be able to cope with a high demand. For this reason, developed countries might also not be able to provide support to poor countries as they will give priority to their own citizens. Also, politicians might use the pandemic as a leverage tool for achieving gains in negotiations with China.
4)The development of a vaccine against the virus is expected for 2021, longer than in other pandemics.
5)China is also trying to avoid the media storm while in trade negotiations with the US, and therefore, might also be providing innacurate data, which eventually will come to the light.

Some background: There have now been five PHEIC's declared by the WHO, starting with Swine flu in 2009. (https://www.theguardian.com/global/2020/jan/30/coronavirus-what-other-public-health-emergencies-has-the-who-declared)  At least superficially, Swine flu might be the 'closest' in (general) similarity of the others to the current Coronavirus outbreak/declaration.  It appears that the WHO ended its declaration for Swine flu approximately 15 months after it was initiated. As another past example, the WHO reportedly ended its PHEIC for Ebola (2014) about 22 months after declaring one. (https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/last-week-world-health-organization-declared-coronavirus-global-health-emergency-what-does-mean-180974128/) Medical experts are currently (still) working to completely understand important aspects of the Coronavirus, including exactly how it spreads, etc. (https://www.statnews.com/2020/02/11/hospitals-governments-need-more-data-to-prepare-for-the-new-coronavirus-outbreak/). 
An effective, tested vaccine is likely several or more months away. (https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/02/12/804628081/timetable-for-a-vaccine-against-the-new-coronavirus-maybe-this-fall). Mainly per the above, initial forecast is with the current 'crowd' estimate: A higher chance (starting at approx. 75%) that the PHEIC will still be in effect as of 5/6/2020.

While the situation is still fairly uncertain in regards to the following factors, I expect the PHEIC to remain in effect. 
- actual population of those infected
- actual rate of transmissibility and R0
- actual CFR
- rate of transmission outside of Hubei
- rate of transmission outside of China PHEIC are alert levels to the health authorities of other countries that govern cooperation and readiness requirements. So at that time, while media coverage may wane or change it’s tone to be more moderate, that is largely divorces from the epidemiological facts on the ground.  The definition taken from Wikipedia (and verified on the official website of the World Health Organization) is as follows:
A Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) is a formal declaration by the World Health Organization (WHO) of "an extraordinary event which is determined to constitute a public health risk to other States through the international spread of disease and to potentially require a coordinated international response", formulated when a situation arises that is "serious, sudden, unusual or unexpected", which "carries implications for public health beyond the affected State's national border" and "may require immediate international action".  As a poor example, the h1n1 swine flu pandemic of which began appearing in April of 2009 met the criteria as a PHEIC and can serve to illustrate the decision making around these declarations. The 2009 swine flu pandemic remained in effect until August 10, 2010. This was only taken out of effect when it was clear that out-of-season transmission had largely stopped, the intensity of transmissions were dropping when defined periods were compared, and there were signs that this strain of influenza was becoming established as a seasonal strain. This the situation was no longer extraordinary [1] [1] https://www.who.int/csr/disease/swineflu/9th_meeting_ihr/en/
Oops, too quick on the button...
Best I can tell, these declarations do not get lifted quickly
Massive under reporting of mild symptoms, plus long a symptomatic incubation period means this is highly likely going to be a global pandemic

I suspect that the spread of the virus will have greatly diminished by early May but new cases will still be appearing on a daily basis and there will still not be a vaccine.   It will not be until at least June that we can expect to see a seasonal relief from the virus. I believe that the WHO will err on the side of caution and uphold the PHEIC until then.

The fatality rate may not be high, but the spread looks to be increasing. Most air travel has not yet been restricted (only from China) so those carriers that have eluded quarantine have already infected terrestrial travellers.
As there is already one case of death in France, this disease should/could no longer be limited to China, hence it will become an international affair.

In the event of vaccinations being prepared and trialled, production capability will not be achieved until far later. The proven transmissability, and the fact that the majority of cases are likely to be undiagnoses at present and appear as a normal cold, means that we can not accurately understand its current prevalence, and given the average case spreads to 2.2 people, I find it impossible to believe in this global era that it can be contained, quarantined and neutralised before then. The only proven effective antiviral medication Lopinavir/ritonavir is mass produced by Abbott and Cipla, neither of which have substantial output extension capability.
The epidemic is estimated to peak in March / April and 30 April, when the WHO meets, will be too soon to remove the PHEIC

America’s Corona-virus Infection Rate is Oddly Low As of February 11, 2020 1600 GMT, Singapore has reported 47 infections while Hong Kong has reported 49. It’s obviously wrong that Singapore has virtually the same number as Hong Kong when Hong Kong has an active, open border with China. Clearly, Hong Kong is under-counting infections for political or capacity reasons. Similarly, Western Europe has reported 43 infections, while the US has reported 13. America’s numbers seem low given Western Europe’s comparable population to the US while the US has a greater number of Chinese nationals to boot. Why is the US infection rate relatively low?  All of this becomes more striking in light of comments on February 11th from Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas on CNBC, “From when the virus began incubating in mid-November until now, there may have been a million and a half arrivals from China to the United States.” Lastly, former FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb wrote in a CNBC Op-Ed on February 10th “Models suggest that for every person who traveled into the U.S. infected with corona-virus, and who was successfully diagnosed and quarantined, maybe three more arrived undetected.”  CDC Corona-virus Testing Process is Slow and Bureaucratic An expert on virus testing that I queried stated that CDC requires corona-virus samples to be sent to state health departments and then on to CDC for testing. This is a slow process that seems outdated when local testing kits can be had for $2 a pop. Mayor Bill DeBlasio is pushing to get the tests out to New York as is Senator Cotton to all 50 states. People Are Careful When Risks Abound A Harvard epidemiologist pointed out that social responses to an epidemic only occur when there are reported cases. Any lack of news about confirmed cases when an infectious disease is prevalent means that people won’t take reasonable precautions.  Trump Obfuscated Troop Injuries in Iraq President Trump suppressed reports of injuries to troops from the Iranian missile attack on US bases in Iraq this past January. He initially tweeted that nobody was hurt. Later, reports emerged that 60 had suffered injuries which the President characterized as “headaches.” The Guardian reported yesterday that over 100 troops had, in fact, suffered traumatic brain injuries – a substantial change from the President’s initial claim. President Trump clearly withheld information to support his immediate political needs. Could President Trump also be delaying confirmed corona-virus infections announcements too? Trump’s Incentives to Delay Facts: Impeachment and Election Given the impeachment vote last week and the current election year battles, the Trump Administration has substantial incentives to suppress bad news. Why? To protect the stock market and consumer confidence as both of which would immediately take a hit on virus news. Without a vaccine, “social distancing” - keeping people apart - is the only way to slow down a virus. And the price for doing this is dramatically slowing down the economy which leads to lost revenue and people losing their jobs.  This is what is happening right now in China and Hong Kong. It is exactly what would cause President Trump to lose the election if it occurred here in America too. The President has substantial incentives to delay new infection reports. President Trump’s reelection strategy is a huge bet on stimulus from cutting taxes, interest rates, and regulation to pump-up the stock market and the economy. If the “sugar high” continues long enough, his gamble is that is that he will win the presidential election in November. Unfortunately, exogenous shocks like a pandemic are exactly what could sink his bet and lead him to losing, much like Super-storm Sandy saved President Obama’s reelection bid in 2012. Ironic that a tiny virus can knock the President out of the White House. I often hear from many of President Trump’s most ardent supporters that they dislike him personally but will vote for him if things are good. Therefore, his margin for error is quite limited should the economy start to turn down. Is Trump Repeating China’s Mistake? Under the pretext of preventing a panic, there is the possibility that President Trump is influencing the CDC’s control of the testing process to determine when infections are announced, if at all.  He might be hoping that it all just goes away. China did exactly this. The authorities in Wuhan sent information to their higher-ups in Beijing who sat on the results.  So, if President Trump is making the same mistake – the result could be catastrophic too if the disease is spreading. And the really big variable which we don’t know yet is if there are “super-spreaders” like the British national who visited Singapore and infected people in France, Spain, and the UK. The CDC designates 68 cases as “Pending” meaning “specimens received and awaiting testing, as well as specimens in route to CDC,” so there is plenty of room for President Trump to suddenly bump the number up to 82.  One Million Students Left Wuhan, China’s Biggest College Town While it is well known that 5 million people left Wuhan before the quarantine commenced on January 23rd, what is less well known, as I was personally told by a Chinese academic, is that Wuhan is China’s biggest college town and that 1 million students left Wuhan before the lock down. What if the transmission speed in Wuhan is linked to the large student population as students are a highly social demographic?  As America’s winter break this year coincided with China’s Lunar New Year, it’s probable that an above-average number of Chinese students went home and returned for the start of spring term. America has 360,000 Chinese university students, more than any other country, and at least 15,000 are in Boston. Could Boston be the Next Wuhan? As America’s biggest college town, Boston has a large student population like Wuhan with a freshly returned population of students from China over the past few weeks – the ingredients exist for an outbreak in Boston. There is currently no public health warning in Boston and the hospitals are not operating at a heightened level of risk mitigation.

While it is still going up 2-3000 a day in China for those diagnosed with Coronavirus I do not see an explosion of cases elsewhere. Apparently there will not be a review until end of April. Unless the numbers begin to rise this is unlikely.
